gw.pl.testharness

Class DebugUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.pl.testharness.DebugUtil

  • public class DebugUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    A utility class with verious methods to aid in debugging.
    Author:
    David Wake

    • Method Detail

      • assertArrayEquals

        public static void assertArrayEquals(java.lang.String[] expected,
                                     java.lang.String[] actual)
        Compares two strings and returns if they are equal but fails with an explanation if they are unequal. This method is useful when a JUnit assert is failing in a test but it is hard to figure out why (for example the string is long but is only one line, in which case IntelliJ doesn't bring up a diff). You can replace 
        assertEquals(s1, s2)
        with 
        DebugUtil.assertEquals(s1, s2)
        to get a far more informative error message.
        Parameters:
        expected -
        actual -

      • assertEquals

        public static void assertEquals(java.lang.String expected,
                                java.lang.String actual)
        Compares two strings and returns if they are equal but fails with an explanation if they are unequal. This method is useful when a JUnit assert is failing in a test but it is hard to figure out why (for example the string is long but is only one line, in which case IntelliJ doesn't bring up a diff). You can replace 
        assertEquals(s1, s2)
        with 
        DebugUtil.assertEquals(s1, s2)
        to get a far more informative error message.
        Parameters:
        expected -
        actual -

      • counter

        Parameters:
        name - The name of the code point to be counted.

      • counter

        public static void counter(java.lang.String name,
                           int max)
        Each time this method is called with a given name, it increments a counter for that name and prints its value to System.err. It will also print out a message after it has been called max times with the given name. Suppose you have a method like this: 
         private void foo() {
   // This method is called thousands of times
   bar();

   // This assertion fails after passing thousands of times
   assertTrue(...);
 }
        You know that the call to bar() is doing something to make the assertion fail, but it's difficult to get to that point in the debugger because the code path is executed so many times. Using a breakpoint with a counter in IntelliJ is an option, but that slows down the test a lot. Instead, do this: 
         private void foo() {
   DebugUtil.debug("foo");

   // This method is called thousands of times
   bar();

   // This assertion fails after passing thousands of times
   assertTrue(...);
 }
        and rerun the test. In your console output, you will see something like this: 
           Hit foo 1234 times
   Hit foo 1235 times
   Hit foo 1236 times
   Assertion failed ...
        Now change the code again, to this: 
         private void foo() {
   DebugUtil.debug("foo", 1236);

   // This method is called thousands of times
   bar();

   // This assertion fails after passing thousands of times
   assertTrue(...);
 }
        And put a breakpoint on the 11th line of this method (where suggested by the comments). Rerun the test in debug mode. You will hit the breakpoint you just created immediately before the call to bar() that causes the test failure. You can then step in the debugger to see what went wrong.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the code point to be counted.
        max - The maximum number times this function should be called with a given name.

      • stringCompare

        public static java.lang.String stringCompare(java.lang.String expected,
                                             java.lang.String actual)
        Compares two strings and returns null if they are equals or an explanation of why they are unequal. This method is useful when a JUnit assert is failing in a test but it is hard to figure out why (for example the string is long but is only one line, in which case IntelliJ doesn't bring up a diff).
        Parameters:
        expected -
        actual -
        See Also:
        assertEquals(String,String)
